PHL 105/195: (Honors) Introduction to Deductive Logic - Fall 2019, Spring 2020, Fall 2020, Spring 2021, Fall 2021

title: Research
text:
Interests: Analysis; Partial Differential Equations; Scattering Theory

Scattering Theory is the study of perturbations on wave propagation. It lives (primarily) at the intersection of partial differential equations, functional analysis, and microlocal analysis.

Master’s Work
For my master’s degree, I completed a project titled The Hardy-Littlewood Maximal Function, advised by Kabe Moen.


Abstract

This project is primarily concerned with the sharp constants in the weak \((1,1)\) inequality and strong \((p,p)\) inequalities for the Hardy-Littlewood maximal function. We begin by providing various (but equivalent) definitions of the Hardy-Littlewood maixmal function. Afterwards, we state and prove the aforementioned inequalities, and end with a summary and (some) proofs of the known sharp constants.



Talks Given

Graduate Student Seminar, University of Missouri, Best Constants for the Hardy-Littlewood Maximal Theorem, Fall 2024 [slides]



Conferences Attended

AMS Fall Central Sectional Meeting, St. Louis, MO, Fall 2025

title: Jacob Lawrence
text:
I am a third year PhD student at the University of Missouri, advised by Tanya Christiansen. Broadly speaking, my mathematical interests are in partial differential equations, especially spectral and scattering theory.
Before coming to the University of Missouri, I finished a BS in Mathematics & Philosophy and an MA in Mathematics from the University of Alabama.
My CV can be found here.

title: Trace Class Operators
text:
\[
    \DeclareMathOperator{\R}{\mathbb{R}}
    \DeclareMathOperator{\tr}{tr}
\]

Recall: given an \(n\times n\) matrix \(A=\begin{pmatrix} a_{jk} \end{pmatrix}_{1\leq j,k\leq n}\), the trace of \(A\) is \[
    \tr A=\sum_{j=1}^n a_{jj},
\] i.e., the sum of the diagonal elements of \(A\). Given an orthonormal basis \(\{\phi_j\}_{j=1}^n\), \[
\tr A=\sum_{j=1}^n \langle Ae_j, e_j\rangle.
\]
We can generalize this as follows:
